awd_titl_txt: Sustaining the USA National Phenology Network
awd_abstract_narration:
The timing of events such as leaf-out, flowering, migration, and hatch are a strong indicator of plant, animal, and ecosystem response to rapidly changing climate conditions.  The USA National Phenology Network (USA-NPN) was established with the primary aim of documenting the timing of such seasonal life cycle events in plants and animals. A primary activity of the USA-NPN is to maintain Nature’s Notebook, a phenology observing program used by thousands of citizen- and professional-scientists for collecting and maintaining phenology information, while approachable enough to be used daily by thousands of volunteer data collectors nationwide. Further, hundreds of higher education institutions and K-12 classrooms nationwide use Nature’s Notebook and consequent data in inquiry-based learning and hands-on exploration of phenology and large datasets. The observations generated through Nature’s Notebook are regularly incorporated into scientific research and publications. 

This award will provide short-term, partial support for USA-NPN team activities. This award enables the USA-NPN to continue to offer a wide range of real-time phenology maps and short-term forecasts, maintain the Nature’s Notebook program and infrastructure, support existing Nature’s Notebook participants and group leaders, and continue to engage with science, research, educator, media, and other end-user communities over the next year. The USA-NPN also offers a growing roster of maps and short-term forecasts to support biological research, planning and management decisions. USA-NPN map and forecast products are also widely referenced in forestry, urban forestry, agriculture, and invasive species management applications.  Over the course of the one-year award, we anticipate growing the Nature’s Notebook database by 4M records, to a total of over 30M phenology records while working to secure long-term and sustainable support.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Through this NSF award, we have been able to continue to carry out the primary functions of the USA National Phenology Network over the reporting period. This has included hosting and expanding Nature’s Notebook, the USA-NPN’s plant and animal phenology monitoring platform. Over the three-year award period, tens of thousands of participants contributed over 10 million phenology records to the platform from many thousands of sites.

Individuals participating in phenology data collection reaped a range of benefits from the activity. Participants in Nature’s Notebook frequently report a richer appreciation for the plants and animals they observe and seeing things they’ve never seen before. Simply encouraging people to go outside and engage with living things has documented and untold benefits. A member of the Tree Spotters Local Phenology Program based at Arnold Arboretum of Harvard University recently remarked, “It's amazing to observe the progression of tree life cycle stages through the years. I've started to really 'see' trees since I started tree spotting with Nature's Notebook. It's because of the education I've received as a participant in this program that I understand trees better.”

Data, information, and resources offered by the USA-NPN are also used by several federal agencies to support management decisions. US Fish and Wildlife Service National Wildlife Refuges use Nature’s Notebook to time restoration activities, track post-fire ecosystem recovery, and maximize effectiveness of invasive species treatments. The Extended Spring Indices have also been included in the USGCRP’s Fifth National Climate, have been used to estimate the impact of increasing likelihood of false springs, and as a proxy for the timing of bird migration. USDA Climate Hubs, University Extension professionals, and NOAA NWS climate and weather specialists frequently reference and circulate these maps as well to warn growers of the potential impacts of early spring and risk of subsequent frosts.

During the reporting period, the USA-NPN team completely overhauled the project website as part of an upgrade from Drupal 7 to Drupal 9. As well, we shifted the entire program’s infrastructure from aging on-premises server hardware to the University of Arizona’s Amazon Web Services. As well, in collaboration with researchers at the University of Florida, the USA-NPN team won a 4-year NSF Capacity grant to completely revamp and improve data input and access apps and tools; this work is currently underway.

Finally, this award enabled the USA-NPN team to work closely with the NobleReach Foundation, an embedded entrepreneur, and consultants in the philanthropy field to better assess alternative ways for the program to generate income and sustain activities. While the effort did not yield clear and easy paths to generating sufficient funds, outcomes are promising for at least partially supporting the program into the future. The work also raised the profile on the University of Arizona campus.
